text.p: The following are the main stories from Monday morning's Austrian newspapers:

- Chancellor Viktor Klima wants to end a stalemate between his ruling Social Democrats and the conservative junior coalition partner, the People's Party, over more flexible working hours by introducing a collective agreement.
- German truckmaker MAN's Austrian unit Steyr Nutzfahrzeuge fears job cuts after a job guarantee extended by MAN expired by the end of the year.
- Lower interest rates will help the government cut its budget deficit this year, the federal financing agency said.
- Austria's constitutional court is looking into the possibility of abolishing communal tax credits enjoyed by state railways OeBB.
- Austria, hosting an expert conference on land mines this week, is pushing for a complete ban on all land mines.
- Conservative party secretary Othmar Karas sees dissent over flexible work hours within his own party.

- Austria's federal debt has risen to nearly 1.4 trillion schillings in 1996, but the increase in the total debt burden eased to 46 billion schillings from 122 billion a year earlier, the federal financing agency said.
- Austria's central bank president Klaus Liebscher is convinced that Austria will be in the first round of countries to join Europe's planned economic and monetary union.
- Trial of "Black Widow" Elfride Blauensteiner, accused of murdering one man, starts in the lower Austrian town of Krems.
- Transport and telecommunications minister Caspar Einem says Austria's telephone charges, among the highest in Europe, must come down.
- Austria's labour costs are the highest within the European Union, causing an extra cost burden of some 60 billion schillings for Austrian companies, economic research institute Wifo says.
- German transport minister Matthias Wissman has called for a boycott of Austrian roads following the introduction of motorway tolls in Austria at the beginning of the year.
- Vienna's stock exchange must be as trustworthy and cheap as its competitors to survive, says Wolfgang Ruttenstorfer, secretary of state for finances.
